title: So China just blacklisted like 30 something anime titles in a row,
body:
Stupid, absolutely shameful.

You know game DRM? Look how well it turns out for the gaming scene!

People are not as uncultured as you might think, they would always find ways around it, always. It's proven time and time again,** stuff like this just won't work.**

So in the end of the day, they would still be enjoying their shiet all while you act like a giant forking wet butt on the international map. I swear the dumbest government officials in the whole world are you and your brother Murica (and a few cousins).

How about putting aside the addiction for that politic poker for once and actually think about your people a little bit, or at the very least, give them some freedom to choose their off time entertainment materials? That would be nice.

Oh you don't want to let kids see things that may not be appropriate for their age? Then get a better age restriction law, education system or something, ANYTHING!  Instead of this nonsense.

**Or is nerfing just easier to do than actual balancing? **
_amiright rito???_

Geez.

/rant

replies.body:
Well it's kinda like what Australia is trying to push right now.

For those that aren't informed, currently going through legislation is a bill that essentially will force Telstra and the rest to have sites that intend to use copyrighted material for free (think free downloads of movies eg. torrent sites) blocked from all Australian users.

The problem is 2 fold with this though.
1. We hardly ever get movies very quickly other then in cinemas, usually being months behind the rest of the world.
2. VPN's won't be blocked (or have been said that they shouldn't be blocked as breaching copyright isn't the primary intention of them), which of course means you will still be able to bypass this if you retain half a brain.

That isn't what the bill does at all. It imposes some degree of liability for copyright breaches at the ISP level, since imposing it at end user level is all but unenforceable. ISPs will be forced to block access to certain content channels to protect themselves from being held liable for what their customers do with them. It will fail spectacularly and be repealed at the next change of government if it does get through.
